Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Award: Resonance Raman Spectroscopic Studies on the Dynamic Structures and Long-Range Electron Transfer of Di-Heme

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Research Initiation Awards (RIAs) provide support to STEM junior faculty at HBCUs who are starting to build a research program, as well as for mid-career faculty who may have returned to the faculty ranks after holding an administrative post or who needs to redirect and rebuild a research program. Faculty members may pursue research at their home institution, at an NSF-funded Center, at a research intensive institution or at a national laboratory. The RIA projects are expected to help further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, to improve research and teaching at his or her home institution, and to involve undergraduate students in research experiences. With support from the National Science Foundation, Tougaloo College will conduct research to understand how heme proteins function in biological systems and what factors regulate their functions. The research project is an interdisciplinary project which will involve students and faculty in the areas of chemistry, physics and biology. The project is expected to expand the research capacity of the College and to promote student and faculty engagement in STEM disciplines. It will contribute to the College's efforts to produce more qualified STEM workers and researchers, especially from underrepresented minority groups.

The goals of this project are to: 1) study the dynamic structure of the di-heme enzyme, MauG, and some mutant MauG proteins; 2) determine the relationship between the dynamic properties and the enzyme function; and 3) identify key structural features that control the dynamic structures and long-range electron transfer properties of the enzyme. Resonance Raman and FTIR spectroscopy along with kinetic studies will be used to achieve these goals. Findings from this work will provide clues as to how the protein is self-regulated to perform the catalytic function while protecting itself from oxidative damage and may also help to elucidate the electron-transfer and catalytic mechanism of other multi-active center proteins or protein complexes. This work is expected to extend the understanding of the structure-function relationship, especially the roles of remote residue in electron transfer. This project will also provide training in variable temperature techniques, and protein expression and purification techniques for undergraduates. These are valuable skills that will allow students to distinguish themselves in the job market and/or give students a competitive edge when applying to graduate schools.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electron transfer (ET) reactions play key roles in many biological processes such as oxidation/reduction,   activation, DNA repair, energy harnessing and many others. Many enzymes are not only catalysts but also matrix for inter- and intra molecular ET among active sites. Controlled ET is one of the primary regulation mechanisms in the biological systems. Understanding how biological systems regulate ET, i.e., which electron transfer processes are feasible and how fast they will occur, is of vital importance.

Metalloproteins (such as copper and iron) play leading roles in electron transport. MauG is a di-heme protein that catalyzes the posttranslational modification of the two endogenous tryptophan residues at the active site of precursor methylamine dehydrogenase (Pre-MADH). The net results of this reaction are the insertion of oxygen at the C6 position of the bTrp57 and the crosslink of bTrp57 and bTrp108 forming a tryptophan tryptophylquinone (TTQ) co-factor of mature MADH. This reaction proceeds via a long-range ET mechanism involving two heme active sites which have different spin and coordination states. The high spin heme, which is distant from the substrate pre-MADH,  reacts directly with oxygen donating substrates (H2O2 or O2).  The low spin heme is closer to the substrate intervened by a tryptophan residue.  Two hemes in MauG, though distant to each other, act cooperatively in electron transfer and catalysis.  The catalytically active species of MauG is a distinct bis-Fe(IV) intermediate (consisted of a Fe(IV)=O and a Fe(IV) species) which is stabilized by the charge-resonance effects involving two heme and a intervening tryptophan residue (Trp93).

This project aims at how the electron-transfer mechanism of MauG is altered and regulated by structural change of the heme active site. Our studies have found that the ferric high spin heme iron in free MauG is an equilibrium of five- and six-coordinated states under the physiological condition, where a substantial fraction of the high spin heme is six-coordination.  Substrate binding to MauG shifts the equilibrium and increases the proportion of five-coordinated heme three-fold. The change of the coordination state of the high spin heme which is 40 Å away from the substrate binding site, alter the mechanism of ferryl heme auto-reduction. In the absence of preMADH the bis-Fe(IV) state spontaneously decays to the di-ferric state over several minutes through auto-reduction. This is a complex multistep reaction involving both proton and ETs. Specifically, the bis-Fe(IV) state first converted to a compound-I like state through proton transfer (PT). The compound-I like state is then auto-reduced to di-ferric state through 2 proton coupled electron transfer reactions. The first ET is coupled to PT to the hemes from solvent via an ordered water network. The second ET is coupled to PT at the methionine group on the distal site resulting in the oxidation of the methionine to a sulfoxide. In the presence of preMADH, the auto-reduction of the bis-Fe(IV) is proceeded through a two-step process with only the Compound II-like intermediate observed and no kinetically detectable Compound I-like intermediate.  RR spectra of ferric MauG at various temperature show that the equilibrium of the five- and six-coordinated states is affected by temperature. At room temperature, a six-coordinated high spin heme is predominant. The equilibrium shifts to have increased proportion of five-coordinated high spin state with decreasing temperature. Therefore, conversion from the six-coordinated state to the five-coordinated state is an exothermic process and the five-coordinated high spin heme is at a lower energy state than the six-coordinated heme. FTIR and RR spectra of the ferrous MauG-CO complex indicate that the two heme coordination states have different electron static potential and changing from 6-coordinated to five-coordinated state involves chain movement.

In summary, this RIA supported research reveals two dynamic coordination states of the high spin heme in MauG, which has not been observed by other spectroscopic and X-ray crystallographic methods. Conversion from a six-coordinated state to a five-coordinated state activates the electron transfer catalytic pathway for biosynthesis. This change is induced by substrate binding at a location 40 Angstrom away. The mechanism that MauG uses to regulate its activities could also exist in other catalytic oxidation-reduction reactions in the biological systems.

The financial support from this RIA project has allowed the PI to establish a Raman Spectroscopy and a Electrochemistry laboratory, a significant expansion of the research capacity of the PI and the college. PI has established collaborations with faculty both inside and outside the college. These Raman and electrochemistry laboratories have also been used to teach Junior/Senior classes exposing students to advance topics and techniques in chemistry, physical chemistry and biochemistry.

Over 10 students participated in this project with support from this project or other programs at Tougaloo College. Students are trained with research skills such as molecular biology, protein isolation and purification, UV-visible spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, electrochemistry and enzyme kinetics. Participating in the project have encourage students to pursue a science career.


Last Modified: 09/28/2018
Modified by: Manliang Feng
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Electron transfer (ET) reactions play key roles in many biological processes such as oxidation/reduction, activation, DNA repair, energy harnessing and many others. Many enzymes are not only catalysts but also matrix for inter- and intra molecular ET among active sites. Controlled ET is one of the primary regulation mechanisms in the biological systems. Understanding how biological systems regulate ET, i.e., which electron transfer processes are feasible and how fast they will occur, is of vital importance. Metalloproteins (such as copper and iron) play leading roles in electron transport. MauG is a di-heme protein that catalyzes the posttranslational modification of the two endogenous tryptophan residues at the active site of precursor methylamine dehydrogenase (Pre-MADH). The net results of this reaction are the insertion of oxygen at the C6 position of the bTrp57 and the crosslink of bTrp57 and bTrp108 forming a tryptophan tryptophylquinone (TTQ) co-factor of mature MADH. This reaction proceeds via a long-range ET mechanism involving two heme active sites which have different spin and coordination states. The high spin heme, which is distant from the substrate pre-MADH, reacts directly with oxygen donating substrates (H2O2 or O2). The low spin heme is closer to the substrate intervened by a tryptophan residue. Two hemes in MauG, though distant to each other, act cooperatively in electron transfer and catalysis. The catalytically active species of MauG is a distinct bis-Fe(IV) intermediate (consisted of a Fe(IV)=O and a Fe(IV) species) which is stabilized by the charge-resonance effects involving two heme and a intervening tryptophan residue (Trp93). The financial support from this RIA project has allowed the PI to establish a Raman Spectroscopy and a Electrochemistry laboratory, a significant expansion of the research capacity of the PI and the college.
